headline: Government and Opposition Clash Over 5.3% Unemployment Rate and Economic Plan
summary: Parliament was dominated by a tense economic debate as new figures revealed the unemployment rate has hit 5.3%, a nine-year high. The Government defended its economic plan and announced major new mining permits, while facing sharp criticism from the Opposition over job losses, controversial changes to climate law, and its approach to homelessness.

topicSummaries.topic: Government and Opposition Clash as Unemployment Hits 5.3%
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The latest figures show 160,000 people are now unemployed, impacting household finances and job security across the country.
topicSummaries.content: The release of September quarter labour market data showing a 5.3% unemployment rate triggered the day's most significant political battle. Finance Minister Nicola Willis and Deputy Prime Minister David Seymour argued the figures were forecast by Treasury under the previous Labour government, attributing the economic downturn to their predecessor's "reckless spending" and resulting inflation. In response, Leader of the Opposition Chris Hipkins and Labour's Barbara Edmonds attacked the government for the 37,000 jobs lost since it took office, a shrinking economy, and the impact on young people, with one in seven now unemployed.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Leader of the Opposition)
keyExchanges.quote: If the unemployment was unacceptable, as he said in September 2023, is it now more unacceptable given 37,000 more people have lost their jobs since then, or does he apply one set of standards for the previous Government and a different set of standards to his own?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon DAVID SEYMOUR (Deputy Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: We have always treated unemployment as a percentage figure. It is currently 5.3 percent. That is around 165,000 people. What's interesting is that in late 2023, the time of the statement the member referred to, the Treasury was forecasting on Labour Party policy settings that unemployment would be 165,000 people.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Removes Paris Agreement Reference from Climate Law
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: This legislative change weakens legal requirements for New Zealand to align its domestic climate targets with its international commitments under the Paris Agreement.
topicSummaries.content: The Government faced accusations of weakening climate change laws after announcing it would remove a reference to "contributing to the global effort under the Paris agreement" from domestic legislation. Green Co-leader Chlöe Swarbrick challenged the move, questioning the Government's commitment to its international obligations. Deputy Prime Minister David Seymour defended the decision, stating that New Zealand's domestic targets were sufficiently ambitious and that the change was necessary to protect local jobs, citing the Portland cement works as an example. He refused to name any external groups who supported the change.

keyExchanges.speaker: Chlöe Swarbrick (Co-Leader—Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Can he name just one individual or group external from the Government and with whom the Government consulted with, who supports the changes that were announced late last night to weaken our climate change laws?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon DAVID SEYMOUR (Deputy Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: Yes, in answer to the member's question, I certainly can. But having the capability doesn't mean that I will. Because, you see, there's a tone in this member's questions... that makes people unwilling to be identified and be able to share their views. So that's why I'm not going to participate in her doxxing and outing of people who have different views.

topicSummaries.topic: Major Mining Permits Worth Over $5B Announced
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The new permits are expected to create hundreds of jobs and generate significant wealth, particularly on the West Coast, but signal a renewed focus on resource extraction.
topicSummaries.content: Resources Minister Shane Jones announced a "golden millennium for mining," revealing the government had issued a 30-year mining permit to Santana, representing "$5 billion to $6 billion worth of wealth." He also announced a further $172 million investment for the Endura mine in Reefton. Jones promoted the moves as crucial for creating 800-900 jobs and boosting regional economies that have been "neglected for far too long," while dismissing environmental objections from what he termed "politicians oozing green elitism."

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon SHANE JONES (Minister for Resources)
keyExchanges.quote: I can announce that we have mounted the crest of a golden millennium for mining. Santana—major investment—has been issued a mining permit for 30 years, over $5 billion to $6 billion worth of wealth, and to the small number of worry warts, allow science and technology to wash away your unnecessary anxieties.

keyExchanges.speaker: Chlöe Swarbrick (Co-Leader—Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Tell us about climate change, Shane.

topicSummaries.topic: Minister Denies Government is Drafting Law to Remove Rough Sleepers
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The exchange raises questions about the government's plans for addressing homelessness in city centres, a sensitive and complex social issue.
topicSummaries.content: Housing Minister Chris Bishop denied the Government is working on legislation to remove rough sleepers from central business districts, following a direct question from Labour's Kieran McAnulty. McAnulty cited comments made by the Police Minister on radio that morning, which suggested legislation was being worked on to move homeless people from CBDs to suburbs. Bishop stated, "The Government isn't" developing such legislation, but confirmed it is "considering a range of different things" to "clean up the CBD" ahead of major events and an expected tourism increase.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Kieran McAnulty (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Why is the Minister denying this when police Minister Mark Mitchell confirmed on Newstalk ZB this morning that "Paul Goldsmith and justice are doing a lot of work around that.", and that legislation to move homeless people from CBDs to the suburbs was, "fully supported by caucus and the Prime Minister."?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon CHRIS BISHOP (Minister of Housing)
keyExchanges.quote: The Government is considering a range of different things in relation to the CBD. It is 8 percent of the country's economy; it is of national significance; and, with the City Rail Link opening next year, the International Convention Centre opening, and an increased push for tourism... the Government, as well as Auckland Council, is of the view that we can make the CBD a more desirable place for everyone to be than it currently is.

topicSummaries.topic: Minister Faces Questions Over Increased Harm to Children in State Care
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: A new report shows a rise in the number of children being abused or neglected while in state care, prompting calls for greater accountability.
topicSummaries.content: Minister for Children Karen Chhour was questioned by the Green Party's Kahurangi Carter over the latest 'Safety of Children in Care' report. Carter highlighted warnings from the Children's Commissioner that the number of children in care being abused or neglected has increased. The Minister acknowledged the report showed "an increase of 23 children and young people having a finding of harm compared to the previous year," calling it "unacceptable." However, she also pointed to a 14% decrease in harm within youth justice and care and protection residences.

keyExchanges.speaker: Kahurangi Carter (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: What does she say to Aroturuki Tamariki chief executive, Arran Jones, and Children's Commissioner, Dr Claire Achmad, who warned, "Overall, the number of children in State care being abused or neglected has increased, and this is unacceptable.", and "We must pay attention to the fact that 10 percent of all children in State care were abused or neglected over the last 12 months."

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon KAREN CHHOUR (Minister for Children)
keyExchanges.quote: What I would say is, yes, definitely, it's unacceptable. No child should be hurt or harmed in this country. If you are taking care of a vulnerable young child in our care, don't hurt them, don't harm them, and take responsibility for your actions...

topicSummaries.topic: Parliament Unanimously Condemns Planned Myanmar Elections as 'Sham'
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: New Zealand's Parliament has formally joined international calls to reject the legitimacy of the Myanmar military regime's planned elections.
topicSummaries.content: In a moment of cross-party unity, the House unanimously passed a motion expressing "grave concern" that the Myanmar military regime's planned elections cannot be free or fair. Foreign Minister Winston Peters moved the motion, which was supported by Labour's Phil Twyford and the Green's Teanau Tuiono, who had both recently been on a fact-finding mission. Speakers labelled the planned vote a "generals' election" designed to create a false sense of legitimacy and called on the international community to stand in solidarity with the people of Myanmar.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon WINSTON PETERS (Minister of Foreign Affairs)
keyExchanges.quote: I move, That this House expresses grave concern that the Myanmar military regime's elections, as currently planned, cannot be free nor fair and will not lead to sustainable peace...

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon PHIL TWYFORD (Labour—Te Atatū)
keyExchanges.quote: The war criminals running Myanmar are planning to hold elections before the end of this year, but this is not a general election; it is a generals' election. It is a cynical repackaging designed to make the military regime look civilian and attract the international legitimacy that the generals so desperately crave. It cannot be free and fair. It is a sham election.

conclusion: The day in Parliament was defined by a stark economic debate over rising unemployment, while the Government also faced intense scrutiny over its policy direction on climate change, mining, and homelessness.
